title: Fire Salamander
text_main: A number of large, stable subpopulations of this salamander exist in Central Europe. Some local subpopulation declines have been observed over parts of its range (e.g. through habitat loss, introduced predatory fish, and increased aridity in Spain). A severe decline has been reported in the Netherlands. Some local subpopulations have disappeared, and its population density has also been reduced in parts of Spain. In Italy, localized declines due to habitat loss have been observed in Apen (F. Ficetola and R. Manenti pers. comm. September 2019). Due to the ongoing decline in the extent and quality of its habitat and the threat of Bsal, the population is continuing to decrease.

title: European Rabbit
text_main: Did you know that European rabbits weren‚Äôt always part of Austria‚Äôs wild landscape? They were once considered exclusive royal pets, kept in medieval hunting parks and monasteries. But like true escape artists, some of them made a break for it‚Äîand today, they‚Äôve established themselves across the countryside, from Vienna‚Äôs city parks to the alpine foothills.

Think rabbits are easy prey? Think again! European rabbits can reach speeds of up to 40 km/h (25 mph) and use unpredictable zigzag running patterns to escape foxes, birds of prey, and even the occasional curious dog. Their powerful hind legs can launch them nearly one meter into the air‚Äîa natural parkour expert!

title: European Pond Turtle
text_main: In the stillness of Europe‚Äôs hidden wetlands, where reeds whisper secrets to the wind, a shadow glides beneath the surface. The European Pond Turtle (Emys orbicularis)‚Äîa relic of an ancient world‚Äîmoves with quiet grace, its golden-flecked shell glistening like an artifact lost in time. Born from sun-warmed nests hidden in the soft banks of rivers and ponds, hatchlings the size of a coin emerge, their journey perilous from the start. They scuttle toward the water, avoiding the watchful eyes of herons and foxes, drawn by an instinct as old as the Ice Age itself. Masters of patience, these turtles can remain motionless for hours, waiting for an unsuspecting frog or fish to drift too close. On summer afternoons, they bask on floating logs, absorbing the sun‚Äôs warmth like tiny, living fossils. But at the slightest disturbance, they vanish beneath the water, slipping into the shadows like ghosts of the marsh. Legends whisper that these ancient swimmers bring wisdom, symbols of endurance and survival. For centuries, they have watched the world change around them, surviving against the odds. And even now, in the hidden corners of Europe, where the waters remain wild and free, the European Pond Turtle endures‚Äîsilent, mysterious, eternal.
